Unfortunately I wasn't able to get any additional information in debugger. I guess, the code has to be instrumented to catch a bad recursion before the overflow happens.

I use conditional breakpoints that check the length of Thread.getStackTrace() to see if it is greater than, say, 200.

It'll be difficult to reproduce this without knowing what code is causing it. And even then, it'll be hard to figure out what is causing the overflow. Unfortunately, I've seen these before...
I was thinking of adding a recursion count variable in one of the methods participating the bad recursion. I'll try with a conditional breakpoint as you suggested.

I have not been able to reproduce this problem.

The call stack implies something like a specialization of a constructor inside the class definition.  Which I'm not sure is even allowed. Unfortunately, I'm a little rusty on templates and have been unable to come up with anything to reproduce this call stack.

Allowed or not, we shouldn't be getting a stack overflow :). I am guessing that it is an error condition which isn't being handled in the semantics code. With the PDOM, you tend to get a lot of error conditions since we only have partial information.

Basically, this isn't something I'd be able to fix by inspection, especially being only spare time here.  If the cause is a modified AST courtesy of the PDOM then I would definitely need some source code to run on.
I'll use this to track the template work in the PDOM.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 147080 ***
